Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2016 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Jason Xu is ?Statistical Analysis of Partially Observed Interacting Particle Systems.? The host institution for the fellowship is the University of California-Los Angeles, and the sponsoring scientist is Kenneth Lange.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project successfully developed fundamental mathematical and computational tools for the analysis of stochastic models with complex dependencies. We derived exact expressions that characterize the finite-time or transient behavior for stochastic models that feature intricate or non-linear interactions, along with fast and accurate methods to compute them numerically. These results are not only mathematically interesting in their own right, but are crucial in statistical inference, and enable classical inferential frameworks to apply when there is missing data as experimental or observational limitations prevent us from observing the process fullly or continuously through time. In particular, new methods from Bayesian sampling perspectives as well as using fast optimization were integrated into statistical frameworks allowing for rigorous inference and model selection. These results contribute broadly to the toolkit that mathematicians, scientists, and practitioners alike can use to analyze emergent data types that may be complex, high-dimensional, and only partially observable. 

In addition to statistical and mathematical methodology, several close collaborations throughout the project have lead to exciting findings in a number of scientific domains. We developed algorithms for fitting previously intractable mechanistic models of hematopoiesis, the process of blood production, to single-cell lineage tracking data in non-human primates, shedding light on cell fate decisions and the structure of cell differentiation that have far-reaching clinical relevance with applications to gene therapy. Similar methods that combine mechanistic, likelihood-based inference with Bayesian data augmentation allowed for the analysis of the interdependent dynamics of disease spread and evolving social contact structure. A better, more nuanced understanding of the interplay between disease status and contact patterns will continue to inform policy decisions and yield more reliable forecasting in the face of emerging epidemics.

Resulting publications appear across top venues in statistics, mathematics, machine learning, and hematology. The algorithms and data are all publicly hosted, with four open-source software packages available at the PI's website. Results were disseminated through conference talks both domestically and internationally, as well as focused workshops that incorporated active graduate student training across disciplines. The broader impact on education and training included not only graduate student mentoring and course development at the host institution (UCLA), but also lecture series as the q-Bio Summer School and summer research mentorship at IPAM. The PI made every effort to train new researchers from a variety of backgrounds as well as from under-represented groups. This diverse group of mentees have each become co-authors on at least one resulting publication, and have gone on to pursue graduate studies in a variety of related fields.
